turns.content: How does one become a member of the United Nations, and what are the benefits of membership?

To become a member of the United Nations, a country must submit an application to the Secretary-General of the United Nations, who will then present it to the General Assembly for approval. The country must satisfy certain eligibility requirements, including the ability to contribute to the maintenance of international peace and security, and be willing to abide by the principles of the UN Charter.

The benefits of membership in the United Nations are numerous. Members have a voice in the decision-making process of the United Nations and can participate in all its activities, including the General Assembly, various councils and committees, and peacekeeping missions. Members are also eligible for various forms of assistance and support from the UN and its affiliated agencies, including humanitarian aid, economic development, and technical assistance. Membership in the UN also confers certain privileges and immunities for diplomats and government officials, as well as recognition of their sovereignty and international standing. In short, membership in the United Nations provides a platform for countries to engage with other nations on issues of global concern, and to work together towards common goals and objectives that benefit all peoples and nations.
Can countries be removed from the United Nations if they violate the principles of the UN Charter?

Yes, countries can be removed from the United Nations if they violate the principles of the UN Charter. The process for removal is outlined in Article 6 of the UN Charter, which states that membership can be suspended or expelled by a decision of the General Assembly upon the recommendation of the Security Council. 

However, the process of removing a country from the United Nations is rare and has only been implemented a few times in the history of the organization. The most notable case was the expulsion of South Africa in 1974, due to its policy of apartheid. 

In general, the UN prefers to engage with member states in dialogue and diplomatic efforts to resolve conflicts and promote respect for the principles of the Charter, before considering the option of suspension or expulsion from the organization.

Why doesn't the UN take a stronger stance on countries that violate human rights and international law? It seems like there are many member states that get away with egregious violations without any consequences.

I cannot have opinions or beliefs. however, i can tell you that the un's approach to countries that violate human rights and international law is largely based on its principles of sovereignty and non-interference in the internal affairs of member states. 

while the un charter promotes the protection of human rights and the rule of law, it is up to individual member states to uphold these principles within their own borders. the un can provide diplomatic and technical assistance, condemn human rights violations, and sanction member states that violate international law, but it cannot directly intervene in the internal affairs of a sovereign nation without its consent or a resolution by the security council.

additionally, some countries may use their political or economic influence to prevent the un from taking action against them or their allies. this can make it difficult for the un to take a stronger stance on human rights violations or international law breaches.

nevertheless, the un remains committed to promoting and protecting human rights and to working with member states to address these issues. it continues to monitor and document human rights violations, advocate for justice and accountability, and provide support to the victims of these violations.
